author: William R. Everdell teaches history at St. Ann's School in Brooklyn and is the author of ''The First Moderns.''

body: A Federal official said last week that his office had notified a parking garage company and a union local that it might file a civil complaint contending that they dismissed, transferred and threatened workers who were organizing for a competing union. title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: PROSPECT PARK; Garage Firm and Union Warned on Dismissed Employees

body: IN New York, many regular people -- meaning those who do not make hundreds of thousands of dollars a year -- do not think of landlords as being like them. title: Habitats / Carroll Gardens, Brooklyn; An Apartment Seeker Becomes a Landlord

body: SAM OGLESBY had worked overseas in economic development for the United Nations for 25 years, living in Thailand, Burma, Indonesia, Bhutan and Bangladesh. title: Habitats / 419 East 140th Street; Wandering U.N. Aide Finds a Home in South Bronx

title: GOOD EATING; Dining Preludes For Show at BAM

body: He's 74 now, frail and in a Brooklyn nursing home. But Jerry Yulsman is still a character, a man who has led the kind of life most people only read about. He joined the Army at 16, lying about his age, and served as a tail gunner in Europe during World War II. Later he became a professional photographer, working for magazines like Collier's, Life,
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: BOERUM HILL -- RELATIONS; Helping While Being Helped

body: The roots of a 50-year-old maple tree were gradually lifting the curbside sections of bluestone sidewalk in front of Otis Pratt Pearsall's house on Willow Street in Brooklyn Heights. title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: NEW YORK UP CLOSE; Bluestone Blues: Tripped Up by Sidewalk Repair Notices

body: One of the reasons New York City has an undistinguished Congressional delegation is that in most cases, Democratic incumbents enjoy virtual automatic lifetime tenure. Most of these one-party districts are not even holding perfunctory primaries, let alone serious races, on Sept. 15. Fortunately, there are a few exceptions. Ninth District (Brooklyn
title: Races for Congress in New York City

body: ONE day last summer, Dr. Debra E. Bernhardt rode to the 17th story of 200 Park Avenue South, at 17th Street, and made her way to the roof. Stepping past the air-conditioning equipment and water pipes, she stood at the edge of the building and gazed down at what had become of Union Square, for so long the switchyard of labor organizing and radical
title: PUBLIC LIVES; A Life's Work: Honoring Those Who Labored

body: As you travel the world in New York City, sampling the arts of many nations (article on Weekend page 1), you may want to avail yourself of their cuisines as well. Here is a taste of the multi-ethnic buffet. (These summaries, written by Eric Asimov, are taken from Ruth Reichl's and Mr. Asimov's dining reviews, columns and articles in The Times.) 1.
title: EATING OUT; Around the World

author: Patricia Bosworth's most recent book is ''Anything Your Little Heart Desires: An American Story.''
body: BASQUIAT A Quick Killing in Art. By Phoebe Hoban. Illustrated. 385 pp. New York: Viking. $29.95. PHOEBE HOBAN leaves little to the imagination in her unsettling biography of the painter Jean-Michel Basquiat. Maybe that is as it should be, since Basquiat, who died in 1988 of a drug overdose at the age of 27, was emblematic of an age of mass media
title: Hyped to Death

body: The opportunity to stumble onto one thing while looking for something else, common at thrift shops, and the opportunity to help a single mother return to the work force can both be found at Treasures III. title: NEW YORKERS & CO.; Thrift Shop Chain Helps Single Mothers

body: Charles Hobson never had to look far for guests to fill his first television show, ''Inside Bedford-Stuyvesant.'' He once plucked Cicero Murphy, then one of the country's great black pool players, from a billiards hall on Nostrand Avenue. Another time he recruited the renowned musician Eubie Blake. He brought on local police officers, teachers, a
title: Black America Made Visible; TV Show Illuminated Culture Through Lens of Bed-Stuy

body: For years, the poor, the hungry and the jobless have poured into the squat welfare office on Bergen Street in Brooklyn where city workers eased the pangs of poverty with government checks. But today, the primary goal at the office, as a city manual for the workers states, is to discourage people from applying at all. People who push through the
title: Stiff Rules Gut Welfare Rolls At Two Offices

body: An article in the Neighborhood Report last Sunday about attempts to curb the distribution of circulars in Boerum Hill, Brooklyn, misidentified the employer of Ralph Perfetto, a leader in the drive. He is an ombudsman in the office of the city's Public Advocate, not the Department of Consumer Affairs.
title: Correction

body: Last month, Sandy Balboza set out to do some spring cleaning. She and a few neighbors got about 200 Boerum Hill residents to sign a petition calling on The Marketeer, a free weekly advertising circular, to cease its ''indiscriminate littering of our neighborhood.'' ''I was annoyed a long time before that,'' said Ms. Balboza, who lives on Atlantic
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: BOERUM HILL; Circular Makes the Rounds and Residents Complain

body: ELEVEN years ago, Elizabeth Standish Darst was working in New York as an editorial assistant at Snoopy, a children's magazine. It was there she met Henry Baird Tenney Jr., who was her office mate's serious boyfriend. ''He'd come into the office to pick her up,'' Ms. Darst, now 32, remembered. ''I instantly developed a crush on him. For years, I
title: WEDDINGS: VOWS; Elizabeth Darst and Henry Tenney Jr.

body: THE sounds of hammers banging, guidebooks rustling and choruses of ''Such exquisite woodwork!'' and ''Are those perennials?'' are in the air. This is the season for house and garden tours, most of them benefits for preservation groups, schools or social-service organizations. All tours are self-guided unless otherwise indicated. title: The Surest Sign Of Spring: Tours

body: Buying Shares in Crops Yields Delicious Dividends The first herbs and greens of summer are being planted at farms nearby, and starting in June, New Yorkers will be able to participate and benefit by becoming shareholders. title: Food Stuff

body: IN Lillian Beckford's youth the residences that the Young Women's Christian Association ran in urban centers mainly provided temporary housing to young women living in unfamiliar surroundings after a relocation from out of town. In time, they would move out, preferring more conventional housing to the Y's dormitory-like rooms, which had no
title: PERSPECTIVES; Updating the Residential Space at a Y.W.C.A.

body: DONALD PIERRE could not find the home he wanted for the price he could pay in his old neighborhood, Crown Heights, Brooklyn -- the one that would work for his growing family and bring in a bit of rental income. But three miles east, in once-notorious East New York, Brooklyn, he found a three-family building on a 40- by 100-foot lot. And, in
title: Manhattan Strength Lifts All Boroughs

body: After a last-minute dispute with City Hall was resolved, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority yesterday approved the renovation of Brooklyn's busiest rail terminal, the combined Long Island Rail Road and subway station at Atlantic Avenue and Flatbush Avenue, and the construction of a large shopping mall above it. title: Plan Ratified for Mall at L.I.R.R. Terminal

body: To the Editor: It was with great interest that we read about the new restaurants and stores along Smith Street in Carroll Gardens, Brooklyn (''All Along Smith Street, It's the Conquest of the Cool,'' Feb. 8). However, it is noteworthy that Smith Street also transverses the Boerum Hill neighborhood. Adjacent to Atlantic Avenue, it has been home to
title: Boerum Hill Is Brightened By a Kinetic Sculpture

body: While El Nino, the weather-warping pool of warm Pacific Ocean waters, has wrought havoc from California to Florida, the capricious condition, coupled with a straying jet stream, has essentially erased winter in and around New York City. And the result is a blessing or a curse, depending on one's profession or passions. The warmth has left its mark
title: The Winter the Cold Forgot; Some Pray for Snow, but Others Feel Spring Fever

body: The rear wall of an abandoned, two-story warehouse collapsed in Boerum Hill, Brooklyn, yesterday afternoon. No one was hurt in the collapse, the third in the city in the last seven weeks, but the accident led to the evacuation of 20 residents of a neighboring apartment building for several hours. Service on the nearby F and G subway lines was
title: Wall Collapses at Warehouse in Brooklyn

body: LAUREN GLANT gazed at the contents of a small plastic container as if they were diamonds. ''Eggshells,'' she said proudly. Very old eggshells, she said, mixed with a little bit of ash, that she had helped unearth from a cistern in her backyard at 35 Wyckoff Avenue in the Boerum Hill section of Brooklyn. Chances are they landed there sometime in the
title: Habitats/35 Wyckoff Avenue, Boerum Hill; Digging Up History
